metadata.title: Precious Metals Trading Knowledge
metadata.source: Compiled from Jim Rickards, Mike Maloney, Kitco Research

chunks.title: Gold-Silver Ratio (GSR) Trading
chunks.content:
The Gold-Silver Ratio (GSR) measures how many ounces of silver equal one ounce of gold. Historical average: 50-60. Current (Dec 2025): ~80-85. Trading signals:

- GSR > 80: Silver undervalued relative to gold. Overweight SLV vs GLD.
- GSR < 50: Silver overvalued. Overweight GLD vs SLV.
- GSR mean reversion: When GSR reaches extremes (>85 or <45), expect reversion within 6-18 months.

Key insight: GSR tends to spike during crises (gold outperforms as safe haven), then mean-reverts as silver catches up during recovery.

chunks.title: Real Interest Rates and Gold
chunks.content:
Gold has strong inverse correlation with real interest rates (nominal rates minus inflation). Key relationships:

- Negative real rates: BULLISH for gold. When inflation > Treasury yields, holding gold has no opportunity cost.
- Real rates below -1%: Strong gold tailwind. 2020-2022 saw gold rally from $1500 to $2000+ with deeply negative real rates.
- Real rates above +2%: BEARISH for gold. Bonds offer positive real return, reducing gold's appeal.

Monitor: 10-Year TIPS yield (DFII10 on FRED) as proxy for real rates.

chunks.title: Dollar Strength (DXY) Correlation
chunks.content:
Gold and the US Dollar have inverse correlation (-0.6 to -0.8 historically). Trading implications:

- DXY falling: BULLISH for gold. Weaker dollar makes gold cheaper for foreign buyers.
- DXY rising: BEARISH for gold. Stronger dollar creates headwind.
- DXY breakdowns below 100: Often trigger gold rallies.

Exception: During severe risk-off (2008, 2020 March), both dollar AND gold can rise as flight-to-safety assets.

chunks.title: Fear Regime Detection
chunks.content:
Precious metals serve as safe-haven during market fear. Regime detection signals:

- VIX > 25 + falling SPY: Fear regime. Overweight GLD (80% GLD, 20% SLV).
- VIX > 35: Panic regime. Gold typically spikes, silver may lag (industrial demand concern).
- VIX < 15: Complacency. Consider reducing precious metals allocation.

Key pattern: Silver underperforms gold during fear spikes, then outperforms during recovery. GSR expands in fear, contracts in recovery.

chunks.title: Silver Industrial Demand
chunks.content:
Silver has dual nature: precious metal + industrial metal. ~50% of silver demand is industrial.

Bullish industrial signals:
- Solar panel demand (silver is key component)
- EV battery technology
- 5G infrastructure rollout
- Global manufacturing PMI > 50

Bearish signals:
- Recession fears (industrial demand drops)
- China slowdown (major consumer)
- Manufacturing PMI < 48

Result: Silver more volatile than gold. Higher beta = larger moves up AND down.

chunks.title: Inflation Hedge Properties
chunks.content:
Gold as inflation hedge - historical evidence:

- 1970s stagflation: Gold rose from $35 to $850 (2400% gain).
- 2020-2022 inflation spike: Gold rose from $1500 to $2000+ (33% gain).
- Long-term: Gold maintains purchasing power over centuries.

Key nuance: Gold hedges UNEXPECTED inflation better than expected. If CPI surprises to upside, gold rallies. If inflation is already priced in, gold may lag.

Triggers for gold as inflation hedge:
- CPI prints above consensus
- Fed behind the curve
- Fiscal deficit expansion
- Money supply (M2) growth

chunks.title: GLD vs SLV ETF Comparison
chunks.content:
ETF selection for precious metals exposure:

GLD (SPDR Gold Shares):
- Expense ratio: 0.40%
- Tracks gold bullion price
- Highly liquid (~$50B AUM)
- 1 share ≈ 1/10 oz gold

SLV (iShares Silver Trust):
- Expense ratio: 0.50%
- Tracks silver bullion price
- ~$10B AUM
- 1 share ≈ 1 oz silver

Alternatives:
- GLDM: Micro gold ETF (0.10% expense ratio) - better for small positions
- GDX: Gold miners ETF (2-3x gold leverage, higher risk)
- SILJ: Junior silver miners (highest risk/reward)

chunks.title: Allocation Framework
chunks.content:
Precious metals portfolio allocation guidelines:

Conservative (5-10% of portfolio):
- 70% GLD, 30% SLV
- Rebalance quarterly
- Purpose: Inflation hedge, diversification

Moderate (10-15% of portfolio):
- 60% GLD, 40% SLV
- Add when GSR > 80 or real rates < 0
- Tactical shifts based on regime

Aggressive (15-25% of portfolio):
- 50% GLD, 30% SLV, 20% miners (GDX)
- Active GSR trading
- Leverage during high-conviction setups

Key rule: Never more than 25% in precious metals. Correlation benefits diminish beyond this level.
